messages.subject: Re: Fwd: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Digest Number 767 degreasing  trucks
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Corky and Sharon, Really, Simple Green?  I used the stuff in the house once and wasn t impressed. Maybe it works better on engine oil!  ...or it was several
messages.messageBody:
Hi Corky and Sharon,
Really, Simple Green? I used the stuff in the house once and wasn't
impressed. Maybe it works better on engine oil! ...or it was several years
ago, so it might be a stronger formulation now. I'll see how it does.
I'm also looking at taking it to a car wash a few towns over where they
'steam' engines and undercarriages. More money, less *me* crawling around
in grease. The longer I spend under the truck, the more attractive that's
getting...
Thanks again,
Heidi


At 03:17 PM 3/18/2003 -0800, you wrote:
>asked it. DH is a mechanic, among other things. He
> > Use Simpley Green for all your degreasing needs
> > on your truck. It is
> > biodegradble an will not hurt your paint or hoses.
> > You can wash truck ,
> > engine wheels , tires an every thing else. You can
> > get it at the famous wall
> > mart store, or most any parts store.
> > I hope this helps,
> > Corky ( husband of Sharon of the Swamp)

messages.subject: Fwd: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Digest Number 767 degreasing trucks
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Heidi You have probably finished, by now, but DH finally wrote an answer. I forwarded your question when you asked it. DH is a mechanic, among other things.
messages.messageBody:
Hi Heidi
You have probably finished, by now, but DH finally
wrote an answer. I forwarded your question when you
asked it. DH is a mechanic, among other things. He
rebuilt my 1980 Bronco, when it had 150,000 miles on
it. It now has over 150,000 more.
Sharon of the Swamp

> Use Simpley Green for all your degreasing needs
> on your truck. It is
> biodegradble an will not hurt your paint or hoses.
> You can wash truck ,
> engine wheels , tires an every thing else. You can
> get it at the famous wall
> mart store, or most any parts store.
> I hope this helps,
> Corky ( husband of Sharon of the Swamp)
>
> ----- Original Message -----

> > > Subject: [AlwaysLearning] Digest Number 767

> > > Topics in this digest:
> > >
> > > 1. Degreasing a Truck - advice?
> > > From: Heidi Wordhouse-Dykema
> > > <heidi@...>
> > >
> > > Hi all,
> > > Well, we're learning all about how to degrease
> an
> > > engine and undercarriage
> > > on a new-to-us '97 F250 4x4 diesel truck named
> > > Betsy. Problem is, the only
> > > ways we can figure to degrease her (using
> > > biodegradable degreasers),
> > > removes the paint from the undercarriage too,
> > > leaving the metal unprotected
> > > (and nevermind my arm is tired from scrubbing!)
> Has
> > > anyone out there
> > > successfully degreased an engine/undercarriage
> > > without stripping the paint
> > > as well? Any helpful hints?
> > >
> > > (We need to clear out the dreck as we'll soon be
> > > switching to using
> > > home-made biodiesel soon and we want to be able
> to
> > > tell by sight if it's
> > > dissolving any of the tubing/etc. Otherwise,
> we'd
> > > leave the dreck alone!)
> > >
> > > Heidi
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
>
